commit_message:
Refactor policy synchronizer

This commit adds the following

1. Move policy and rule synchronizer to new class from policy engine
2. support sync of single datasource policy
3. Expose synchronizer endpoints via PE to listen to broadcast requests for
   synchronization
4. update the functions to synchronize one policy instead looping through
   all policies everytime.

Partially-Implements blueprint refactor-synchronizer
Change-Id: I0fc4822daf6c49e6885471530a072caa03ce492b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/60/401960/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 NEC Corp. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # import eventlet from futurist import periodics from oslo_concurrency import lockutils from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from congress.datalog import base from congress.db import db_policy_rules from congress.db import datasources from congress.dse2 import data_service LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) SYNCHRONIZER_SERVICE_ID = '_policy_rule_synchronizer' class PolicySynchronizer(data_service.DataService): def __init__(self, service_obj): super(PolicySynchronizer, self).__init__(SYNCHRONIZER_SERVICE_ID) self.engine = service_obj self.sync_thread = None self.periodic_tasks = None def start(self): super(PolicySynchronizer, self).start() callables = [(self.synchronize_all_policies, None, {})] self.periodic_tasks = periodics.PeriodicWorker(callables) self.sync_thread = eventlet.spawn_n(self.periodic_tasks.start) LOG.info("started policy synchronizer on node %s", self.node.node_id) def stop(self): if self.periodic_tasks: self.periodic_tasks.stop() self.periodic_tasks.wait() self.periodic_tasks = None if self.sync_thread: eventlet.greenthread.kill(self.sync_thread) self.sync_thread = None super(PolicySynchronizer, self).stop() @lockutils.synchronized('congress_synchronize_policies') def sync_one_policy(name, datasource=True): """ Synchronize single policy with DB. """ if datasource: policy_object = datasources.get_datasource_by_name(name) else: policy_object = db_policy_rules.get_policy_by_name(name) if policy_object is None: if name in self.engine.policy_names(): self.engine.delete_policy(name) LOG.info("sync_one_policy, policy deleted %s", name) return if datasource: if name not in self.engine.policy_names(): self.register_datasource_with_pe(name) return p = policy_object.to_dict() if name not in self.engine.policy_names(): self.engine.create_policy( p['name'], id_=p['id'], abbr=p['abbreviation'], kind=p['kind'], desc=p['description'], owner=p['owner_id']) LOG.info("synchronized, policy added %s", name) elif p != self.engine.policy_object(policy_name).get_attr_dict(): # if same name but not identical attributes # replace by new policy obj according to DB self.engine.delete_policy(policy_name) self.engine.create_policy( p['name'], id_=p['id'], abbr=p['abbreviation'], kind=p['kind'], desc=p['description'], owner=p['owner_id']) LOG.info("synchronizer, policy replaced %s", name) def register_datasource_with_pe(self, ds_name): if not self.node.is_valid_service(ds_name): # datasource service not up, nothing to register return # Get the datasource schema to sync the schema with PE schema = self.rpc(ds_name, 'get_datasource_schema', {'source_id': ds_name}) self.engine.initialize_datasource(ds_name, schema) LOG.info("registered datasource with PE %s on node %s", ds_name, self.node.node_id) def sync_datasource_policies(self): added = 0 removed = 0 db_datasources = [ds['name'] for ds in self.node.get_datasources()] ds_policies = self.get_engine_policies(datasource=True) for ds in db_datasources: # check if ds is registered with PE if ds not in ds_policies: self.register_datasource_with_pe(ds) added = added + 1 # get the policies registered with PE , but not in database remove_policies = list(set(ds_policies) - set(db_datasources)) for p in remove_policies: self.engine.delete_policy(p) removed = removed+1 LOG.info("synchronize datasource policies, added %d removed %d ", added, removed) def get_engine_policies(self, datasource=False): policies = [self.engine.policy_object(n) for n in self.engine.policy_names()] if datasource: policies = [p for p in policies if p.kind == base.DATASOURCE_POLICY_TYPE] active_policies = [] for policy in policies: active_policies.append({'id': policy.id, 'name': policy.name, 'abbreviation': policy.abbr, 'description': policy.desc, 'owner_id': policy.owner, 'kind': policy.kind}) return active_policies @periodics.periodic(spacing=cfg.CONF.datasource_sync_period, run_immediately=True) @lockutils.synchronized('congress_synchronize_policies') def synchronize_all_policies(self): LOG.info("synchronize_policies, presioduic taskstarted") # Read policies from DB. db_policies = [p.to_dict() for p in db_policy_rules.get_policies()] # Read policies from engine active_policies = self.get_engine_policies() added = 0 removed = 0 # sync engine policies with DB for p in active_policies: if p not in db_policies: LOG.info("removing policy %s", str(p)) self.engine.delete_policy(p['id']) removed = removed + 1 for p in db_policies: if p not in active_policies: LOG.info("adding policy %s", str(p)) self.engine.create_policy(p['name'], id_=p['id'], abbr=p['abbreviation'], kind=p['kind'], desc=p['description'], owner=p['owner_id']) added = added + 1 self.sync_datasource_policies() LOG.info("synchronize_policies, added %d removed %d ", added, removed) class PolicySynchronizerEndpoints(object): def __init__(self, service): self.service = service def synchnonize_policies(self, context): return self.service.synchronize_all_policies() def synchronize_one_policy(self, context, policy_name): return self.service.sync_policy(policy_name)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/71/419171/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ==================================== Compute Server Architecture Overview ====================================amount of memory, network requirements and the quantity of storage required for each hypervisor as well as any requirements for bare metal hosts provisioned through ironic. When architecting an OpenStack cloud, as part of the planning process, the architect must not only determine what hardware to utilize but whether compute resources will be provided in a single pool or in multiple pools or availability zones. Will the cloud provide distinctly different profiles for compute. For example, CPU, Memory or local storage based compute nodes. For NFV or HPC based clouds, there may even be specific network configurations that should be reserved for those specific workloads on specific compute nodes. This method of designing specific resources into groups or zones of compute can be referred to as bin packing. .. note:: In a bin packing design, each independent resource pool provides service for specific flavors. Since instances are scheduled onto compute hypervisors, each independent node's resources will be allocated to efficiently use the available hardware. While bin packing can separate workload specific resources onto individual servers, bin packing also requires a common hardware design, with all hardware nodes within a compute resource pool sharing a common processor, memory, and storage layout. This makes it easier to deploy, support, and maintain nodes throughout their lifecycle. Increasing the size of the supporting compute environment increases the network traffic and messages, adding load to the controllers and administrative services used to support the OpenStack cloud or networking nodes. When considering hardware for controller nodes, whether using the monolithic controller design, where all of the controller services live on one or more physical hardware nodes, or in any of the newer "shared nothing" control plane models, adequate resources must be allocated and scaled to meet scale requirements. Effective monitoring of the environment will help with capacity decisions on scaling. Proper planning will help avoid bottlenecks and network oversubscription as the cloud scales.OpenStack cloud. To further group compute nodes and place nodes into appropriate availability zones and host aggregates, additional work is required. It is necessary to plan rack capacity and network switches as scaling out compute hosts directly affects data center infrastructure resources as would any other infrastructure expansion. While not as common in large enterprises, compute host components can also be upgraded to account for increases inintensive or memory intensive. Since OpenStack schedules workload placement based on capacity and technical requirements, removing compute nodes from availability and upgrading them using a rolling upgrade designThe ability to create pools or availability zones for unpredictable workloads should be considered. In some cases, the demand for certain instance types or flavors may not justify individual hardware design. Allocate hardware designs that are capable of servicing the most common instance requests. Adding hardware to the overall architecture can be done later.
deleted_lines: ========= Overview =========amount of memory, and the quantity of storage required for each hypervisor. Determine whether compute resources will be provided in a single pool or in multiple pools. In most cases, multiple pools of resources can be allocated and addressed on demand, commonly referred to as bin packing. In a bin packing design, each independent resource pool provides service for specific flavors. Since instances are scheduled onto compute hypervisors, each independent node's resources will be allocated to efficiently use the available hardware. Bin packing also requires a common hardware design, with all hardware nodes within a compute resource pool sharing a common processor, memory, and storage layout. This makes it easier to deploy, support, and maintain nodes throughout their lifecycle. Increasing the size of the supporting compute environment increases the network traffic and messages, adding load to the controller or networking nodes. Effective monitoring of the environment will help with capacity decisions on scaling.OpenStack cloud. Additional processes are required to place nodes into appropriate availability zones and host aggregates. When adding additional compute nodes to environments, ensure identical or functional compatible CPUs are used, otherwise live migration features will break. It is necessary to add rack capacity or network switches as scaling out compute hosts directly affects data center resources. Compute host components can also be upgraded to account for increases inintensive or memory intensive.The ability to add Compute resource pools for unpredictable workloads should be considered. In some cases, the demand for certain instance types or flavors may not justify individual hardware design. Allocate hardware designs that are capable of servicing the most common instance requests. Adding hardware to the overall architecture can be done later.

commit_message:
Add releasenotes and python35 jobs to Tricircle

Currently no releasenotes and python35 jobs in Tricircle, the
releasenotes job is basic job to publish a release, and python35
is a common goal for the OpenStack community, so it's time
to add these jobs to Tricircle project.

At the same time, the xenial dvsm job is stable in Tricircle, it's
time to convert it to voting job.

Depends-On: I18cb59cadb7a1c06f6cd729c4bda2c8e95d41e1e

Change-Id: I20936840d0ea73f4b272172cedb0c6b759d6c0cc
Signed-off-by: joehuang <joehuang@huawei.com>

commit_message:
Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: I7b995e76e64fb868a6908622c4b0a40acbd58d8d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/58/419158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

added_lines: --- security: - | Updated file permissions for CVE-2016-9590. Fixes configuration file permissions for the proxy server and storage servers. The permissions were getting incorrectly changed from 0640 to 0644 due to lack of the explict setting of mode on the concat resources.

commit_message:
Migrate neutron-fwaas API definitions to neutron-lib

As part of the Neutron Stadium, neutron-fwaas must migrate it's API
definition to neutron-lib.

Needed-By: I57504f97ac39b5b7d301fd5cc88228a121f0677e

Change-Id: I7b4108772e8370e8f51971caf40ecd23e9f977e9

commit_message:
Revisit exported policy module

The primary goal of the library policy module is to support
the context module during the enforcement of service and
admin rules, and as such an enforcer is needed. Incidentally
the enforcer is stored in a global variable whose name is the
same as the enforcer's used by neutron's policy engine.

To avoid confusion, this patch revises some parts of the
library's policy module to make sure the cut of responsibilities
is better defined. It finally makes the policy module private
to avoid any danger of mixing up the enforcer instances.

Change-Id: Ie55d557aa3e24678aed2fb3b5c590485f54fe792
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/45/419245/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Isolate one _ROLE_ENFORCER per test case mock.patch.object(policy, '_ROLE_ENFORCER', None).start() def test_init_reset(self): self.assertIsNone(policy._ROLE_ENFORCER) self.assertIsNotNone(policy._ROLE_ENFORCER)
deleted_lines: # Isolate one _ENFORCER per test case mock.patch.object(policy, '_ENFORCER', None).start() def test_init_reset_refresh(self): self.assertIsNone(policy._ENFORCER) self.assertIsNotNone(policy._ENFORCER) policy.reset() self.assertIsNone(policy._ENFORCER) policy.refresh() self.assertIsNotNone(policy._ENFORCER)

subject: fix ambigous cinder error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-12 23:33:57.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/tables/actions.py', 'openstack_dashboard/dashboards/project/volumes/volumes/tables.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/74f9a8faf81fad84ec368ad43f932a2c602c9a25', 'message': 'fix ambigous cinder error

Let cinder give the detailed error when trying to remove
a volume that has a snapshot rather than displaying
Error: You are not allowed to delete volume:

Fixes-Bug: 1584288

Change-Id: Id735d1b54cfeb477dab006fc495ad8841c1a298f
'}]
commit_message:
fix ambigous cinder error

Let cinder give the detailed error when trying to remove
a volume that has a snapshot rather than displaying
Error: You are not allowed to delete volume:

Fixes-Bug: 1584288

Change-Id: Id735d1b54cfeb477dab006fc495ad8841c1a298f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/90/419690/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return (volume.status in DELETABLE_STATES)
deleted_lines: return (volume.status in DELETABLE_STATES and not getattr(volume, 'has_snapshot', False))

subject: Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-11 23:36:17.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/authtoken_manage_memcache_package-55f01f617aaa8db0.yaml', 'spec/classes/zaqar_keystone_authtoken_spec.rb', 'manifests/keystone/authtoken.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-zaqar/commit/aaaa38c198734b9aee4b3d32491c2473c1fc943b', 'message': 'Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: Id0d980618cd3816172e491b20058d540d6d1ed41
'}]
commit_message:
Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: Id0d980618cd3816172e491b20058d540d6d1ed41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-zaqar refs/changes/97/419197/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :manage_memcache_package => true, it 'installs python memcache package' do is_expected.to contain_package('python-memcache') end

commit_message:
Improve Quick Start documentation

Made improvents to the quickstart guide

Moved the troubleshooting section from quickstart guide to a new
document troubleshooting.rst

Change-Id: I0f08d8743682390b2fe8071ab2484e251f2ef803

subject: Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-11 23:20:55.000000000', 'files': ['spec/classes/gnocchi_keystone_authtoken_spec.rb', 'releasenotes/notes/authtoken_manage_memcache_package-a83630efd64e36a0.yaml', 'manifests/keystone/authtoken.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-gnocchi/commit/3a34b190ed6d447f6aef27e101a37c56ab86d16b', 'message': 'Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: Ib6fede2f42f618f0a2fcbacf3da5f9b7e8606be5
'}]
commit_message:
Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: Ib6fede2f42f618f0a2fcbacf3da5f9b7e8606be5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-gnocchi refs/changes/93/419193/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*manage_memcache_package*] # (Optional) Whether to install the python-memcache package. # Defaults to false. # $manage_memcache_package = false, manage_memcache_package => $manage_memcache_package,

subject: Support last modified on listing containers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-06 08:25:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/f11c91addaf3a17e422dc3fe1c306a50b2174486', 'message': 'Support last modified on listing containers

For now, last modified timestamp is supported only on
object listing. (i.e. GET container)

For example:

GET container with json format results in like as:

[{"hash": "d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230", "bytes": 0, "name": "object",
"content_type": "application/octet-stream"}]

However, container listing (i.e. GET account) shows just a dict
consistes of ("name", "bytes", "name") for each container.

For example:

GET accounts with json format result in like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container"}]

This patch is for supporting last_modified key in the container listing
results as well as object listing like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230"}]

This patch is changing just output for listing. The original timestamp
to show the last modified is already in container table of account.db as
a "put_timestamp" column.

Note that this patch *DOESN'T* change the put_tumestamp sematics.
i.e. the last_modified timestamp will be changed only at both PUT
container and POST container. (PUT object doesn't affect the timestamp)

Original discussion was in working session at Vancouver Summit.
Etherpads are around here:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-swift-contributors-meetup
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-container-listing-update

TODO:
Add response example to https://github.com/openstack/api-site

DocImpact

Change-Id: Iba0503916f1481a20c59ae9136436f40183e4c5b

'}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2015-12-07 06:30:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/a6ec4e6658fa92ac81b768e45f4fe6d18d156e89', 'message': 'Support last modified on listing containers

For now, last modified timestamp is supported only on
object listing. (i.e. GET container)

For example:

GET container with json format results in like as:

[{"hash": "d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230", "bytes": 0, "name": "object",
"content_type": "application/octet-stream"}]

However, container listing (i.e. GET account) shows just a dict
consistes of ("name", "bytes", "name") for each container.

For example:

GET accounts with json format result in like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container"}]

This patch is for supporting last_modified key in the container
listing results as well as object listing like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230"}]

This patch is changing just output for listing. The original
timestamp to show the last modified is already in container table
of account.db as a "put_timestamp" column.

Note that this patch *DOESN'T* change the put_tumestamp sematics.
i.e. the last_modified timestamp will be changed only at both PUT
container and POST container.
(PUT object doesn't affect the timestamp)

Original discussion was in working session at Vancouver Summit.
Etherpads are around here:

commit_message:
Support last modified on listing containers

For now, last modified timestamp is supported only on
object listing. (i.e. GET container)

For example:

GET container with json format results in like as:

[{"hash": "d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230", "bytes": 0, "name": "object",
"content_type": "application/octet-stream"}]

However, container listing (i.e. GET account) shows just a dict
consists of ("name", "bytes", "name") for each container.

For example:

GET accounts with json format result in like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container"}]

This patch is for supporting last_modified key in the container
listing results as well as object listing like as:

[{"count": 0, "bytes": 0, "name": "container", "last_modified":
"2015-06-10T04:58:23.460230"}]

This patch is changing just output for listing. The original
timestamp to show the last modified is already in container table
of account.db as a "put_timestamp" column.

Note that this patch *DOESN'T* change the put_timestamp semantics.
i.e. the last_modified timestamp will be changed only at both PUT
container and POST container.
(PUT object doesn't affect the timestamp)

Note that the tuple format of returning value from
swift.account.backend.AccountBroker.list_containers is now
(name, object_count, bytes_used, put_timestamp, 0)

* put_timestamp is added *

Original discussion was in working session at Vancouver Summit.
Etherpads are around here:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-swift-contributors-meetup
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/liberty-container-listing-update

DocImpact

Change-Id: Iba0503916f1481a20c59ae9136436f40183e4c5b

commit_message:
Allow to pass suite flavor to gate_hook to disable dvr tests

Now if a job explicitly passes 'dvrskip' as a second argument to
gate_hook, then those tests requiring dvr extension won't be executed.

Needed-By: I0e94c5d7f65bbb1d803df0d2f99389ae19556480
Change-Id: I05233e69801be27cc35211148a53af02af29c8a5

commit_message:
Fix quota show output

Currently Quota Show expects dictionary to be returned
for Network client, similar to Volume and Compute clients, but
Network Object is being returned, causing the "openstack quota show"
to fail.
This patch takes care of this issue.

Depends-On: Ie0e045ff4888615d68804fd739d5b995ca11e9a1

commit_message:
Fix list metric for other tenants

1. Use get_x_tenant_or_tenant_id instead of get_tenant_id in list
metrics api.
2. Add missing delegateAuthorizedRole config to devstack api-config.yml

Change-Id: I18c0dd340a4ac8b016e761d648d9f03923b070bc
Closes-bug: #1613997

commit_message:
Fix gate broken by auth_ref in image unit test

Sometimes Jenkins check failed by the error:

openstackclient/image/v2/image.py", line 875, in take_action
    project_id = self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id'
"AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'project_id'".
Log in [1]

This change try to fix this problem.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/85/418685/3/check/gate-python-openstackclient-python35/fe25c5f/console.html#_2017-01-12_06_18_50_571756

Change-Id: I800007f9cce4ff0555856ebb453571a3f7ebc4ff
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/45/419445/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.app.client_manager.auth_ref = mock.Mock() self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id = self.project.id self.project.id,

commit_message:
Fix image member unit tests occasional failures

Let's try just unrolling the member status tests and not getting
too fancy here.

Change-Id: I30022ebd2da6d6cf1abba424d7d7fa679285f291

added_lines: def test_image_set_membership_option_accept(self): self.app.client_manager.auth_ref = mock.Mock() self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id = self.project.id arglist = [ '--accept', image_fakes.image_id, ] verifylist = [ ('accept', True), ('reject', False), ('pending', False), ('image', image_fakes.image_id) ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.image_members_mock.update.assert_called_once_with( image_fakes.image_id, self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id, 'accepted', ) # Assert that the 'update image" route is also called, in addition to # the 'update membership' route. self.images_mock.update.assert_called_with(image_fakes.image_id) def test_image_set_membership_option_reject(self): membership = image_fakes.FakeImage.create_one_image_member( attrs={'image_id': image_fakes.image_id, 'member_id': self.project.id} ) self.image_members_mock.update.return_value = membership self.app.client_manager.auth_ref = mock.Mock() self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id = self.project.id arglist = [ '--reject', image_fakes.image_id, ] verifylist = [ ('accept', False), ('reject', True), ('pending', False), ('image', image_fakes.image_id) ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.image_members_mock.update.assert_called_once_with( image_fakes.image_id, self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id, 'rejected', ) # Assert that the 'update image" route is also called, in addition to # the 'update membership' route. self.images_mock.update.assert_called_with(image_fakes.image_id) def test_image_set_membership_option_pending(self): membership = image_fakes.FakeImage.create_one_image_member( attrs={'image_id': image_fakes.image_id, 'member_id': self.project.id} ) self.image_members_mock.update.return_value = membership self.app.client_manager.auth_ref = mock.Mock() self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id = self.project.id arglist = [ '--pending', image_fakes.image_id, ] verifylist = [ ('accept', False), ('reject', False), ('pending', True), ('image', image_fakes.image_id) ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.image_members_mock.update.assert_called_once_with( image_fakes.image_id, self.app.client_manager.auth_ref.project_id, 'pending', )

commit_message:
Fix exception for multiple devices with same label

This fixes the exception message that is raised when there are
multiple devices with the same label. Instead of including the
original device path, it was showing one of the device's name
& label.

The message now includes the original device path along with
the two devices that have the same label.

Change-Id: Id114b25e95492686bc6679e217d4963d6a3ed0c4
Related-Bug: #1654269

commit_message:
Pin beaker-puppet_install_helper to 0.5.0

beaker-puppet_install_helper 0.6.0 included the switch to puppet agent
by default since the EOL of puppet3. Since Mitaka has some modules that
don't support puppet4 (I'm looking at you puppet-swift), we need to pin
it.

Change-Id: Icb466a9662ae34eedeb3fb65bcb618775cb97d5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_spec_helper refs/changes/89/419689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # pin to 0.5.0 because 0.6.0 switched to puppet agent which breaks puppet-swift spec.add_dependency 'beaker-puppet_install_helper', ['0.5.0']

commit_message:
Fix beaker under centos

beaker-puppet_install_helper 0.6.0 has made the PUPPET_INSTALL_TYPE now
default to agent which was the previous behavior we had when running
under puppet 4. Since puppet 3 is now officially EOL, this switches the
defaut to assume puppet agent packaging rather than the foss version.

Change-Id: I3243f9d7bdb19840f6462c5b6b237c2314a71fbe
(cherry picked from commit 6d5803d05a6e308e3c315c2689f1cec031d21fad)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack-integration refs/changes/24/419624/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(aschultz): since puppet 3 is now EOL, and beaker-puppet_install_helper # version 0.6.0 has made the agent version the default, we need to symlink # puppet to the /opt/puppetlabs version when specifically not version 3. if [ "${PUPPET_MAJ_VERSION}" = 3 ]; thenelse export PUPPET_BASE_PATH=/etc/puppetlabs/code export PATH=${PATH}:/opt/puppetlabs/bin # Workaround to deploy puppet for beaker jobs sudo -E ln -sfn /opt/puppetlabs/bin/puppet /usr/sbin/puppet

commit_message:
Update Python classifiers

Project which supports python 3 should specify it using just major version and
then for every subversion should specify it. Remove also 3.4 classifier as
OpenStack decided about dropping support for this release completely.

Change-Id: I9beb6ef2df4c96f2f92e4f75e900f16eae9e325b

commit_message:
Correct the paramters of l7 policy creation

This patch correct the undefined parameter "l7policy_dict" to
l7policy.to_dict() in l7policy creation.

Change-Id: I81c53e36a4a616fed530c2c4ae307d50554b2894

commit_message:
unskip network qos rule type functional test

with the SDK at 0.9.12 the below test fails with:

'minimum_bandwidth' not in

+-----------------+
| Type            |
+-----------------+
| dscp_marking    |
| bandwidth_limit |
+-----------------+

So remove 'minimum_bandwidth' from the asserted fields.

Change-Id: I24ff691ae5a946d901afa763973305025829280b
Closes-Bug: 1653137
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/29/419129/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'bandwidth_limit']

commit_message:
Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: I3a6f847e4d5ff64e09b664dc58b17db4094c814c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/81/419181/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Decompose router extra attr processing

This adjusts the extra router attributes mixin to add
a new function to explicitly set the value of an extra
attribute. The mixins that depend on extra attrs
now explicitly call this instead of depending on a big
inheritance chain of calling _process_extra_attr_router_create.

This will allow the router_az, DVR and HA modules to eventually
be separated from the L3 plugin class inheritance entirely.

Related: blueprint multi-l3-backends
Change-Id: If44bfef9428f43dd82758928bf46786b70e5e11c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/04/417604/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.callbacks import events from neutron.callbacks import registry from neutron.callbacks import resources def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs): inst = super(ExtraAttributesMixin, cls).__new__(cls, *args, **kwargs) registry.subscribe(inst._router_create_extra_attr_callback, resources.ROUTER, events.PRECOMMIT_CREATE) return inst def _router_create_extra_attr_callback(self, resource, event, trigger, context, router, router_db, **kwargs): """Event handler to avoid explicit calls from mixins for defaults.""" self._process_extra_attr_router_create(context, router_db, router) self._ensure_extra_attr_model(context, router_db) router_db['extra_attributes'].update(kwargs) def _ensure_extra_attr_model(self, context, router_db): if not router_db['extra_attributes']: new = l3_attrs.RouterExtraAttributes(router_id=router_db['id']) context.session.add(new) router_db['extra_attributes'] = new def set_extra_attr_value(self, context, router_db, key, value): # set a single value explicitly for attr in self.extra_attributes: if attr['name'] == key: self._ensure_extra_attr_model(context, router_db) router_db['extra_attributes'].update({key: value}) return raise RuntimeError("Tried to set a key '%s' that doesn't exist in " "the extra attributes." % key)
deleted_lines: # extra_attributes reference is populated via backref if not router_db['extra_attributes']: attributes_db = l3_attrs.RouterExtraAttributes( router_id=router_db['id'], **kwargs) context.session.add(attributes_db) router_db['extra_attributes'] = attributes_db else: # The record will exist if RouterExtraAttributes model's # attributes are added with db migrations over time router_db['extra_attributes'].update(kwargs)

commit_message:
Fix Gentoo builds on Ubuntu 16.04 Xenial hosts

Xenial's bind of /dev into the chroot includes /dev/shm which is in
use by the host.  An alternitive fix for this would be to use rbind
to recursivly bind mount /dev instead of just the base bind of /dev

Change-Id: I2c0f70afd1e82dd52a522f0dd2b3ea618b30b6c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/95/413395/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # make /dev/shm dir if it doesn't exist # mount tmpfs and chown it # don't care about anything still using it # that which was still using it will still # hold it's file descriptor open as needed if [[ ! -d /dev/shm ]]; then if [[ ! -e /dev/shm ]]; then mkdir /dev/shm fi # unmount tmpfs # care about anything still using it if fuser /dev/shm; then rmdir /dev/shm fi
deleted_lines: if [[ -L /dev/shm.orig ]]; then rm /dev/shm.orig if [[ -d /dev/shm.orig ]]; then rm -Rf /dev/shm.orig fi mv /dev/shm /dev/shm.orig mkdir /dev/shm rmdir /dev/shm mv /dev/shm.orig /dev/shm

commit_message:
Allow python-memcache install from authtoken class

The python-memcache package is required if using memcached. By
default the package is not installed and the define has it set to
false. This change allows managing the python-memcache package
install from the authtoken class.

Change-Id: I7de3338061bad949f26ed0d84782124c7b61eb70

specific job.

commit_message:
Add debootstrap-minimal element for diskimage-builder

Change-Id: Iba49004558893421b9ed1e48887ca21f21b7dcaa
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs refs/changes/39/419139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Rootfs elements for diskimage-builder ===================================== By creating rootfs elements diskimage-builder can effectively produce debootstrap containers. Which can then be used into docker or runc. Problem Description =================== Today the smallest image one can produce with diskimage-builder, is using the -minimal elements. For example, ubuntu-minimal will build an image from scratch using debootstrap, however it does additional steps (install python, kernels) which use case is for a VM. While the -minimal element can be use for containers, there isn't a need for kernel packages to be installed. Proposed Change =============== Overview -------- Split the debootstrap element into debootstrap / debootstrap-minimal. Where the debootstrap-minimal element will invoke debootstrap with the --variant=minbase flag. The debootstrap-minimal element does have any element-deps to avoid installing unnecessary applications into the chroot. We then create ubuntu-rootfs and debian-rootfs elements, which depend on debootstrap-minimal, creating the smallest possible chroot to work with. Alternatives ------------ Not use diskimage-builder to create container things. For example, a simple bash script to invoke debootstrap directly would be another way to achieve this. Security Impact --------------- N/A Other End User Impact --------------------- New ubuntu-rootfs / debian-rootfs elements will be available to create debootstrap only images / tarballs. Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other Deployer Impact --------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pabelanger Work Items ---------- * Split debootstrap element into debootstrap / debootstrap-minimal. * Create ubuntu-rootfs operating system element, element-deps on debootstrap-minimal. * Do the same for debian-rootfs. * Write validation tests. * Update nodepool dsvm job to build rootfs elements. Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= We can leverage the existing nodepool dsvm job to ensure rootfs elements are properly created. Documentation Impact ==================== Update develop docs to reference new elements. References ========== N/A

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-01-05 20:38:14.000000000', 'files': ['nova/api/openstack/placement/deploy.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/aeecfe09c463d0b14f8f525234d25eb0ef4c5523', 'message': "[placement] fix typo in call to create auth middleware

used, and instead the config was loaded in the normal way. This
worked because the config loaded by the project name is the same
as the config loaded otherwise.

There's no test coverage of this in unit and functional tests
because the NoAuthMiddleware is always used based on overridden

Change-Id: I9f1b8905fd9d5aadac61718e24c76b1b2f80410d
Closes-Bug: #1645306

commit_message:
[placement] fix typo in call to create auth middleware

The typo meant that the intended non global config was not being
used, and instead the config was loaded in the normal way. This
worked because the config loaded by the project name is the same
as the config loaded otherwise.

There's no test coverage of this in unit and functional tests
because the NoAuthMiddleware is always used based on overridden
configuration. The gate tests that turn on placement will exercise
this code.

Change-Id: I9f1b8905fd9d5aadac61718e24c76b1b2f80410d
Closes-Bug: #1645306

commit_message:
Allow suppression of warnings from DriverManager

Some projects (e.g. Neutron) using the DriverManager with
another fallback mechanism when the alias doesn't exist don't
want the "Could not load warning" messages in the logs.

This patch allows the warn_on_missing_entrypoint kwarg to be
passed to DriverManager which passes it up to its parent
NamedExtensionManager.

Change-Id: Ia6f5f749fc2f73ca6091fa6d58506fddb058902a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/stevedore refs/changes/11/418011/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support agentless driver in neutron-dynamic-routing

Some BGP driver is agentless, but the neutron-dynamic-routing is
bound to RPC driver so closely. So the codes need to be refactored.

Change-Id: Id134faa2d08369a7ad7aab1d353b83b1fbc4d48f
Related-Bug: #1611632
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/29/373029/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================== neutron-dynamci-routing agentless driver ======================================== [RFE] neutron_dynamic_routing project is bound to rpc driver closely https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1611632 Problem Description =================== The current module `BgpPlugin.py` is bound to RPC driver so closely, so it is not working well with the agent-less driver. Another problem is the neutron-dynamic-routing project does not follow the service provider registration mechanism. Currently, for all advanced service features, all projects are using service provider to load the driver, so from this view, the neutron-dynamic-routing project needs to be refactored. Proposed Change =============== Refactor the current neutron-dynamic-routing code to make sure all agent/agent-less drivers work well. 1. Make BgpPlugin.py as an overall interface to load different BGP drivers. The service name will be DYNAMIC_ROUTING. 2. Add a new configuration file neutron_dynamic_routing.conf to specify the service_providers 3. The existing bgp_dragent.ini will be used by the RPC driver such as RYU driver and quagga driver 4. Create a new directory to locate the BgpRpcPluginDriver. The BgpRpcPluginDriver will do what the current BgpPlugin did, for example, setup rpc and register callback. Configuration file impact ========================= Add a new neutron_dynamic_routing.conf to specify the service_providers. service_provider = DYNAMIC_ROUTING:PRCDriver:neutron_dynamic_routing.services.bgp.service_drivers.rpc_bgp.BgpRpcPluginDriver:default References ========== https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lbaas/blobl/master/neutron_lbaas/services/loadbalancer/plugin.py

commit_message:
Use parameter skip_op_id in compute.virt.vmware.test_vsphere_operations

oslo.vmware began to use key-workd paramerter skip_op_id in method
vim.RetrievePropertiesEx in 6a63362919c12023798458e721a4818e61702e3a,
which broke job periodic-ceilometer-py27-with-oslo-master[1], so add
parameter skip_op_id in ceilometer's tests to avoid failure in the
future.

[1]http://logs.openstack.org/periodic/periodic-ceilometer-py27-with-oslo-master/327f794/testr_results.html.gz

Change-Id: I0d25f94136568f4d77928f12e0ba430118827fdb

commit_message:
mech driver v2: build dict for sg on update

precommit callback for security group precommit doesn't pass
complete information. So build it in callback as bug work around.
precoomit callback should be passed full information.
Once it's fixed, this bug work around should be removed.
The original bug report[1] is filed for ODL, but it turned out
the issue resides in neutron and networking-odl

[1] https://bugs.opendaylight.org/show_bug.cgi?id=7256

Change-Id: I15b6f5321cd3e860de7ba50dd5dde8672259c9ba
Related-bug: #1546910
(cherry picked from commit 194da19e84ddabaa2237bd8f971ac331298e3620)

commit_message:
tripleo-quickstart: Alter default -extras req file to use zuul fetched repo

tripleo-quickstart uses tripleo-quickstart-extras by installing it into
a virtualenv it creates, issuing a pip install -r requirements.txt .
The requirements file contains a reference to the git repository. When
quickstart-extras is instead fetched by zuul cloner, we need to specify
a local reference to be installed in the process.
The simplest way is to patch the requirements file on the fly, changing
the git: part with a file: part containing the absolute path to the zuul
fetched repo.

Change-Id: I4ce2cf278e5307484d32ac5dc3845534a9731712
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/23/402123/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sed -i -e "s#git+https://.*/tripleo-quickstart#file://$PWD/tripleo-quickstart#" ./tripleo-quickstart/quickstart-extras-requirements.txt

commit_message:
Workarounds to bug https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1371617

Set cpu mode=none on the undercloud guest xml definition and in hiera
overrides for nova.
looks like https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1371617 affects
also combinations using kvm.
Setting undercloud to disable cpu mode, and override cpu mode for nova

Change-Id: Ibf7b81f1ed8078c22760c342c73807ab547d19b1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/18/410718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Abort in RESCUEWAIT should be supported

Nit fix to spec to indicate that abort should be supported in
RESCUEWAIT.

commit_message:
Add caching to get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node

Instead of calling list_nodes() and get_node_interfaces(node['id']) for each
node in returned list cache devops node id to nailgun node id mapping and
use get_node_by_id instead. As a result there will be less logs in
sys_test.log and it will be easier to read them as
get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node is used quite extensively.

Change-Id: Ied8230c65d795104dffca80ee26514909afc80e5
Closes-Bug: 1656037

added_lines: # Dictionaries that contain fuel-devops node to nailgun node # mapping data self._devops_nailgun_mapping = {} # devops to nailgun node id mapping self._nailgun_node_nics = {} # nailgun node nics macs cache def _update_nailgun_node_nics(self): Retrieve list of nodes from nailgun, for each node retrieve list of network interfaces and put mac addresses of those NICs to self._nailgun_node_nics dictionary for use by _find_nailgun_node_id_for_devops_node function. :return: """ break except exceptions.ClientException: logger.debug('Failed to get list of nodes', exc_info=True) for node in nodes: node_nics = self.client.get_node_interfaces(node['id']) logger.debug('Node id:%s name:%s nic_macs:%r', node['id'], node['name'], macs) self._nailgun_node_nics[node['id']] = macs logger.debug('Resulting nailgun node nics dictionary: %r', self._nailgun_node_nics) def _find_nailgun_node_id_for_devops_node(self, devops_node): """ Find Nailgun node id based on set of devops_node NIC macs. :param devops_node: fuel-devops node object :return: Nailgun node id or None """ devops_macs = {netaddr.EUI(iface.mac_address) for iface in devops_node.interfaces} for node_id, nailgun_macs in self._nailgun_node_nics.items(): # nailgun_macs can contain some interfaces if devops_macs.issubset(nailgun_macs): return node_id return None @logwrap def get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node(self, devops_node): """Return slave node description. Returns dict with nailgun slave node description if node is registered. Otherwise return None. """ # First get Nailgun node id assert devops_node is not None if devops_node.id in self._devops_nailgun_mapping: nailgun_node_id = self._devops_nailgun_mapping[devops_node.id] logger.debug('Found cached devops -> nailgun mapping: %s -> %s', devops_node.id, nailgun_node_id) else: # Find nics in cached self._nailgun_node_nics nailgun_node_id = self._find_nailgun_node_id_for_devops_node( devops_node) if nailgun_node_id is None: # Update self._nailgun_node_nics with new values self._update_nailgun_node_nics() # Try to find node again nailgun_node_id = self._find_nailgun_node_id_for_devops_node( devops_node) # If not found after mac address cache update, try finding # node by name (if BONDING is True) if BONDING and nailgun_node_id is None: # On deployed environment MAC addresses of bonded network # interfaces are changes and don't match addresses # associated with devops node nailgun_node = self.get_nailgun_node_by_base_name( devops_node.name) if nailgun_node is not None: nailgun_node_id = nailgun_node['id'] # Cache devops node id -> nailgun node id mapping self._devops_nailgun_mapping[devops_node.id] = nailgun_node_id logger.debug('Caching devops -> nailgun mapping: %s -> %s', devops_node.id, nailgun_node_id) # Then retrieve Nailgun node dict using Nailgun node id if nailgun_node_id is not None: return self.client.get_node_by_id(nailgun_node_id) else: return None
deleted_lines: import traceback @logwrap def get_nailgun_node_by_devops_node(self, devops_node): """Return slave node description. Returns dict with nailgun slave node description if node is registered. Otherwise return None. d_macs = {netaddr.EUI(i.mac_address) for i in devops_node.interfaces} logger.debug('Verify that nailgun api is running') attempts = 0 except Exception: logger.debug(traceback.format_exc()) logger.debug('Look for nailgun node by macs %s', d_macs) for nailgun_node in nodes: node_nics = self.client.get_node_interfaces(nailgun_node['id']) logger.debug('Look for macs returned by nailgun {0}'.format(macs)) # Because our HAproxy may create some interfaces if d_macs.issubset(macs): nailgun_node['devops_name'] = devops_node.name return nailgun_node # On deployed environment MAC addresses of bonded network interfaces # are changes and don't match addresses associated with devops node if BONDING: return self.get_nailgun_node_by_base_name(devops_node.name)

commit_message:
Automatically convert process_input to bytes

On py35, if process_input is a string we end with an Error:
TypeError: memoryview: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'

A whole lot of code in os-brick/cinder/neutron currently need
to be fixed. Hardest problem is tracking down every instance of
this problem and trying to test/fix it at source. See example
of cinder/os-brick/oslo.rootwrap/oslo.privep code problem here:
http://logs.openstack.org/43/418643/2/check/gate-rally-dsvm-py35-cinder-nv/6efa7b5/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz?level=ERROR

It's just better to fix it in one spot and pass the correct
thing to subprocess.communicate

Change-Id: I88d1510a7ba4c020f73452f0b80e996c22b1edf1

added_lines: def test_rewrite_measures_oldest_mutable_timestamp_eq_next_key(self): """See LP#1655422""" # Create an archive policy that spans on several splits. Each split # being 3600 points, let's go for 36k points so we have 10 splits. apname = str(uuid.uuid4()) ap = archive_policy.ArchivePolicy(apname, 0, [(36000, 60)]) self.index.create_archive_policy(ap) self.metric = storage.Metric(uuid.uuid4(), ap) self.index.create_metric(self.metric.id, str(uuid.uuid4()), apname) # First store some points scattered across different splits self.storage.incoming.add_measures(self.metric, [ storage.Measure(utils.dt_to_unix_ns(2016, 1, 1, 12, 0, 1), 69), storage.Measure(utils.dt_to_unix_ns(2016, 1, 2, 13, 7, 31), 42), storage.Measure(utils.dt_to_unix_ns(2016, 1, 4, 14, 9, 31), 4), storage.Measure(utils.dt_to_unix_ns(2016, 1, 6, 15, 12, 45), 44), ]) self.trigger_processing() splits = {'1451520000.0', '1451736000.0', '1451952000.0'} self.assertEqual(splits, self.storage._list_split_keys_for_metric( self.metric, "mean", 60.0)) if self.storage.WRITE_FULL: assertCompressedIfWriteFull = self.assertTrue else: assertCompressedIfWriteFull = self.assertFalse data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451520000.0', "mean", 60.0) self.assertTrue(carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451736000.0', "mean", 60.0) self.assertTrue(carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451952000.0', "mean", 60.0) assertCompressedIfWriteFull( carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) self.assertEqual([ (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 1, 12), 60.0, 69), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 2, 13, 7), 60.0, 42), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 4, 14, 9), 60.0, 4), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 6, 15, 12), 60.0, 44), ], self.storage.get_measures(self.metric, granularity=60.0)) # Now store brand new points that should force a rewrite of one of the # split (keep in mind the back window size in one hour here). We move # the BoundTimeSerie processing timeserie far away from its current # range. # Here we test a special case where the oldest_mutable_timestamp will # be 2016-01-10TOO:OO:OO = 1452384000.0, our new split key. self.storage.incoming.add_measures(self.metric, [ storage.Measure(utils.dt_to_unix_ns(2016, 1, 10, 0, 12), 45), ]) self.trigger_processing() self.assertEqual({'1452384000.0', '1451736000.0', '1451520000.0', '1451952000.0'}, self.storage._list_split_keys_for_metric( self.metric, "mean", 60.0)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451520000.0', "mean", 60.0) self.assertTrue(carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451736000.0', "mean", 60.0) self.assertTrue(carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1451952000.0', "mean", 60.0) # Now this one is compressed because it has been rewritten! self.assertTrue(carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) data = self.storage._get_measures( self.metric, '1452384000.0', "mean", 60.0) assertCompressedIfWriteFull( carbonara.AggregatedTimeSerie.is_compressed(data)) self.assertEqual([ (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 1, 12), 60.0, 69), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 2, 13, 7), 60.0, 42), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 4, 14, 9), 60.0, 4), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 6, 15, 12), 60.0, 44), (utils.datetime_utc(2016, 1, 10, 0, 12), 60.0, 45), ], self.storage.get_measures(self.metric, granularity=60.0))

commit_message:
Add dummy API definitions for extension subresources

This change introduces the dummy definitions for extension
subresources, and its related testing coverage. It was
observed in a few definition proposals (e.g. [1]) that this
was a missing element in the description of a neutron extension.

The enhancement got reflected in the existing definitions, such
as trunk and trunk_details, and thus amends were made to these
to show how to use the dummy suggestions in practice.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/413182

Change-Id: I5eb36cdf99039f2e74c93735fcddd5953c7fe086

commit_message:
A script that pulls the latest puppet source

A script to download the latest puppet modules from source.
This works well with the upload-puppet-modules script.
There are options to pull the latest source or skip
an update if the module already exists.

Author: Wes Hayutin <weshayutin@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Martin Andre <m.andre@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5ee8ec1e54f02c7b39331a56b9bcc36d5a1055f2

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. MODULES=" aodh ceilometer ceph cinder glance gnocchi heat horizon ironic keystone manila midonet mistral neutron nova openstack_extras openstacklib oslo pacemaker sahara swift tempest tripleo trove vswitch zaqar " MODULE_DIR=$HOME/puppet-modules mkdir $MODULE_DIR pushd $MODULE_DIR for module in $MODULES; do if [ -d $module ]; then pushd $module git pull popd else git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/puppet-$module $module fi done popd

commit_message:
Stop running if zuul job goes away

At times we are ending up with significantly more testenvs running
than we have zuul jobs.  The current theory is that this happens
when a zuul job is removed before completion, possibly when a new
patch set is pushed or a change is abandoned.  Because our test
jobs are unaware of zuul they continue to run even though infra
thinks the job has been stopped.  This can cause us to exceed the
quota for the nodepool user.

This patch attempts to deal with the problem by periodically
querying the zuul status endpoint and looking for the ZUUL_UUID
value in the output.  If it's not found the job will be killed.

Change-Id: I31a8157366a6ec91d8a0befeadc51eca8d8225e1
Closes-Bug: 1655489
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/15/418615/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Kill the testenv if the zuul job disappears. This can happen if a new patch # set is pushed while a job on a previous one is still running. # Only check every 5 minutes to avoid hammering the status endpoint. ( while :; do sleep 300; curl http://zuul.openstack.org/status.json | grep -q $ZUUL_UUID || sudo kill -9 $$ ) &

commit_message:
Blueprint for HSM fail safe

This blueprint discusses and defines the addtion of an HSM fail
safe in barbican.

Co-Authored-By: Sungjin Yook <sungyook@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I5869589a53a0ed4a8efe486c9f24218d6650290f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican-specs refs/changes/97/301997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============= HSM fail-safe ============= Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/barbican/+spec/hsm-fail-safe Problem Description =================== Currently when connection to an HSM is lost, barbican is rendered unusable. There is no fail safe in place to allow operation to continue with another HSM after failure. Proposed Change =============== The proposed change is to allow a backup HSM to be used if the main HSM fails. Anytime the main HSM returns a PKCS11 Error then the same request is sent to the backup HSM. Backup HSM login **************** .. code-block:: ini [p11_crypto_plugin_backup] # Password to login to PKCS11 session for the backup HSM backup_login = 'mypassword' # Label to identify master KEK in the backup HSM (must not be the same as HMAC label) backup_mkek_label = 'an_mkek' # Label to identify HMAC key in the backup HSM (must not be the same as MKEK label) backup_hmac_label = 'my_hmac_label' # HSM slot id for backup HSM backup_slot_id = 2 This section in the configuration is used to specify an HSM to send the request to if the first HSM returns a failure code. Backup HSM policy ***************** .. code-block:: ini [p11_crypto_plugin_backup_policy] # Keeps sending request to failed HSM, if False will continue to use backup fall_back = True This section will contain any relevant policies for the backup HSM. The plugin code for PKCS-11 will be adjusted to be able to switch HSMs on record of a failure. Alternatives ------------ * HSM in HA-mode which has a significant hit on performance. * Backup HSM, but Barbican will still fail on error. Notifications & Audit Impact ---------------------------- Notifications must be sent for on which HSM is being used and its status. Other deployer impact --------------------- If the HSM failsafe feature is put in place the deployer must setup the new HSM. Deployer must also be aware of the configuration changes needed to configure the failsafe. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: * diazjf * mixos Work Items ---------- * Adjust PKCS-11 Plugin to be able to switch HSMs * Add configuration for HSM backup Testing ======= Unit tests must be written for internal component testing. Functional tests must be written for testing this new feature as a whole. Documentation Impact ==================== Barbican admin cloud guide must be updated to include these changes.

commit_message:
Relax conditions on neutron tasks rerun

Some of the changes in node configuration, e.g. controller
addition requires re-run of neutron tasks. This change
ensures that we rerun them on network_metadata changes

Change-Id: Iba4cae9794b5a0ec0ccf03390cbde9a122e9d5e0
Closes-bug: #1654203

commit_message:
Implement thread pool for network verification

By default network checker runs ping to every ip
in a thread simultaneously, depending on HW packets
lost is possible, parallel_amount allows to configure
how many pings should be run in parallel.

Also add constraint on amount of connectivity checker
tasks.

Change-Id: I3aec37a2f50470cf905bccac34a6f79d2d5065d0
Closes-bug: #1653301
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/15/415915/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: newparam(:parallel_amount) do desc 'Amount of package senders run in parallel' defaultto 20 validate do |val| if val.to_i <= 0 raise ArgumentError, "parallel_amount should be positive integer, not '#{val}'" end end munge do |val| val.to_i end end

commit_message:
Symlink API documentation

This may be squashed into the symlink implementation patch at

added_lines: - X-Symlink-Target - X-Symlink-Target-Account - X-Symlink-Target - X-Symlink-Target-Accountoperation. Although using this method, there is no way to specify a symlink as a source without the link being followed for the COPY.You may copy a zero-byte object in order to create a symlink by specifying the target object on the COPY request. If you include the ``symlink=true`` query parameter on a COPY, then the source symlink will be copied with its target header, as opposed to any symlink target headers on the request. - X-Symlink-Target - X-Symlink-Target-AccountA DELETE request made to a symlink path will delete the symlink rather than the target object. - X-Symlink-Target - X-Symlink-Target-Account

commit_message:
Proposed use case form

Change-Id: I67fb176a4d2226a79ebd1385012dd3a261a2aea6
Implements: blueprint use-case-form
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/docs-specs refs/changes/86/391786/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================== Use Case Collection Form ======================== Problem description =================== The OpenStack user and operator community want to be able to provide input for use cases to help provide direction for OpenStack projects and provide possible usage models for the architecture guide. The current methods of using either the dev-list or through blueprints can be quite daunting to newcomers and non-developers. We need to a simple way for operators to provide input and collect feedback. Proposed change =============== The proposal is to create a web form to collect use cases and user stories, the output from the form can then be categorised by keyword and presented in a blog post style, allowing for further questions to be asked or other comments. The form would need to include input fields to collect the following: #. Summary #. Detailed breakdown #. General Notes #. Related Project (optional) #. Theme #. Release #. Company (optional, but highly desired) #. Email Address The number of input fields could be extended, but we should keep in mind that we want to make it simpler for people to provide input. The intention is make this a living process to support input and information gathering. A simple voting mechanism that allows other operators to indicate that they have the same use case would also be useful. Alternatives ------------ Create a google form. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * Other contributors: * shaunom Work Items ---------- * Reach a consensus on the form requirements * Create the web from * Create the blog page mechanism Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Testing will follow the standard documentation review process. References ========== * Discussion can occur using any official medium including IRC in #openstack-doc, the openstack-docs mailing list with [use-case-form] in the subject, biweekly Ops Guide specialty team meeting, weekly documentation team meeting, and potentially etherpads. * This related to a discussion held during the Ocata Docs planning session in Barcelona. .. _`Ocata Planning etherpad`: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/BCN-Docs-OcataPlanningWG

commit_message:
devstack: improve odl-release definition

This patch improves odl release definitions.
Odl release definition is mostly trivial and it can be generated
based on its release name for most common cases.
Generate necessary parameters for odl releases if they are missing
so that future unknown releases can be handled without modification.

Change-Id: I56b559254948935554125b1175995e0d85a9401b
(cherry picked from commit d8e2ec52256b61d7f2b31f6513286c87d60ff286)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/58/418058/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ -r $NETWORKING_ODL_DIR/devstack/odl-releases/$ODL_RELEASE ]; then source $NETWORKING_ODL_DIR/devstack/odl-releases/$ODL_RELEASE fi source $NETWORKING_ODL_DIR/devstack/odl-releases/common $ODL_RELEASE

commit_message:
Return uuid attribute for aggregates

Adds a Compute API microversion that triggers returning an aggregate's UUID
field. This field is necessary for scripts that must populate the placement API
with resource provider to aggregate relationships, which rely on UUIDs for
global identification.

APIImpact
blueprint: return-uuid-from-os-aggregates-api
Change-Id: I4112ccd508eb85403933fec8b52efd468e866772
Closes-bug: #1652642
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/31/415031/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2.41 ---- The 'uuid' attribute of an aggregate is now returned from calls to GET `/os-aggregates`. This attribute is auto-generated upon creation of an aggregate. The `os-aggregates` API resource endpoint remains an administrator-only API.

Ensure extras-common depends on common

subject: Change node search and validation methods
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-12-24 00:17:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/7a73bbe69b84db8a33d13a7eb45f4af66de14d5f', 'message': "Change node search fallback method to system uuid

The previous implementation used a fallback matching rule where
it would match a node if any of its MACs are identical to any
of the MACs already in DB. This is not reliable because MACs can
sometimes be identical due to hardware specifics or other reasons.

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,
which is reliably unique for both hardware and virtual systems,
and also constant for a given system unless it's motherboard is
replaced.

Change-Id: I49855e2b5ff30559cb2385a03abb8cfdd6a5f1f2
Closes-Bug: 1650646
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-12-24 01:15:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/883efb3056918bd89d5c1f26a7e841fa18112273', 'message': "Change node search fallback method to system uuid

The previous implementation used a fallback matching rule where
it would match a node if any of its MACs are identical to any
of the MACs already in DB. This is not reliable because MACs can
sometimes be identical due to hardware specifics or other reasons.

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,
which is reliably unique for both hardware and virtual systems,
and also constant for a given system unless it's motherboard is
replaced.

This change adds a randomly generated UUID to the default node metadata
in tests

Change-Id: I49855e2b5ff30559cb2385a03abb8cfdd6a5f1f2
Closes-Bug: 1650646

"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2016-12-25 07:36:39.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/b3f8348c563b25694910563d299ce7445fd311f1', 'message': "Change node search fallback method to system uuid

The previous implementation used a fallback matching rule where
it would match a node if any of its MACs are identical to any
of the MACs already in DB. This is not reliable because MACs can
sometimes be identical due to hardware specifics or other reasons.

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,
which is reliably unique for both hardware and virtual systems,
and also constant for a given system unless it's motherboard is
replaced.

This change adds a randomly generated system uuid to the default_metadata
in tests

Closes-Bug: 1650646
Change-Id: I49855e2b5ff30559cb2385a03abb8cfdd6a5f1f2
"}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2016-12-25 08:16:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/be11af38acb77eb52063811c3c12df4f6e7da6f4', 'message': 'Change node search and validation methods

- Remove searches by any MAC
- Add search by system uuid
- Allow duplicate MACs except "mac" property

The previous implementation used a fallback matching rule which
would match a node if any of its MACs are found in the database.
This is not reliable because MACs can sometimes be identical due to
hardware specifics or other reasons.

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,
which is reliably unique for both hardware and virtual systems,
and also constant for a given system unless it's motherboard is
replaced.

This change allows nodes to have identical MACs, except "mac" property
which is required to be unique for each node - to ensure that PXE
and related functionality works as expected.

User is responsible for ensuring that interfaces with identical MACs
(if any) are not assigned to the same networks, which will obviously
lead to deployment & connectivity issues.

This change adds a randomly generated system uuid to the default_metadata
in tests.

Closes-Bug: 1650646
Change-Id: I49855e2b5ff30559cb2385a03abb8cfdd6a5f1f2

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,

commit_message:
Change node search and validation methods

- Remove searches by any MAC
- Add search by system uuid
- Allow duplicate MACs (except "mac" property)

The previous implementation used a fallback matching rule which
would match a node if any of its MACs are found in the database.
This is not reliable because MACs can sometimes be identical due to
hardware specifics or other reasons.

This change removes matching by any MAC with matching by system uuid,
which is reliably unique for both hardware and virtual systems,
and also constant for a given system unless it's motherboard is
replaced.

This change allows nodes to have identical MACs on iterfaces.
However, "mac" property still has to be unique.

User is responsible for ensuring that interfaces with identical MACs
(if any) are not assigned to the same networks, which will obviously
lead to deployment & connectivity issues.

This change adds a randomly generated system uuid to the default_metadata
in tests.

Closes-Bug: 1650646
Change-Id: I49855e2b5ff30559cb2385a03abb8cfdd6a5f1f2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/64/414664/33 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Find node by mac, id or system uuid. :param meta: dict with node metadata def _get_uuid(meta): if 'system' in meta and 'uuid' in meta['system']: return meta['system']['uuid'] if node: return node if 'meta' in meta and _get_uuid(meta['meta']): for n in [n for n in db().query(cls.model) if _get_uuid(n.meta)]: if _get_uuid(meta['meta']) == _get_uuid(n.meta): return n
deleted_lines: """Search for instance using mac, node id or interfaces. :param meta: dict with nodes metadata if not node: can_search_by_ifaces = all([ meta.get('meta'), meta['meta'].get('interfaces')]) if can_search_by_ifaces: node = cls.search_by_interfaces(meta['meta']['interfaces']) return node @classmethod def search_by_interfaces(cls, interfaces): """Search for instance using MACs on interfaces. :param interfaces: dict of Node interfaces :returns: Node instance """ return db().query(cls.model).join( models.NodeNICInterface, cls.model.nic_interfaces ).filter( models.NodeNICInterface.mac.in_( [n["mac"].lower() for n in interfaces] ) ).first()

commit_message:
Enable IPA client install

The puppet-ipaclient package is available in delorean.
Therefore, we can enable the requires directive that will
perform the ipa-client-install.

Depends-On: I8e9bd4ed859cc438a309d9a00dd278c65dbb822d
Change-Id: I6732af38d0f815d29cf4fa65149a54c8fb2c6527
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/77/418677/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if $enable_ipa_client_install { require ::ipaclient }
deleted_lines: # Keep this commented out until puppet-ipaclient is available # This will invoke ipa-client-install # # if $enable_ipa_client_install { # require ::ipaclient # }

commit_message:
Run heat-api under mod_wsgi with apache2

This change aligns with the Ocata cinder package, which has
moved the cinder-api to run under mod_wsgi with apache2.

Change-Id: I0d8670d277f1f671f2c654cc0d7a80975d652f50
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Introduce Handlers for V2 API

Introduce the base Handlers for the V2 API as a part
of the alignment process to LBaaSV2 and introduction
of new V2 API.

Change-Id: Ibfe9d8b0fb1df71f44832f6520b36516cfef31b9

added_lines: # Copyright 2014 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License.# Copyright 2014 Rackspace # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import abc from oslo_config import cfg import oslo_messaging as messaging import six from octavia.api.v2.handlers import abstract_handler from octavia.common import constants from octavia.common import data_models cfg.CONF.import_group('oslo_messaging', 'octavia.common.config') @six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta) class BaseProducer(abstract_handler.BaseObjectHandler): """Base queue producer class.""" @abc.abstractproperty def payload_class(self): """returns a string representing the container class.""" pass def __init__(self): topic = cfg.CONF.oslo_messaging.topic self.transport = messaging.get_transport(cfg.CONF) self.target = messaging.Target( namespace=constants.RPC_NAMESPACE_CONTROLLER_AGENT, topic=topic, version="1.0", fanout=False) self.client = messaging.RPCClient(self.transport, target=self.target) def create(self, model): """Sends a create message to the controller via oslo.messaging :param model: """ model_id = getattr(model, 'id', None) p_class = self.payload_class if isinstance(model, data_models.HealthMonitor): model_id = model.pool_id p_class = PoolProducer.PAYLOAD_CLASS kw = {"{0}_id".format(p_class): model_id} method_name = "create_{0}".format(self.payload_class) self.client.cast({}, method_name, **kw) def update(self, data_model, updated_model): """sends an update message to the controller via oslo.messaging :param updated_model: :param data_model: """ model_id = getattr(data_model, 'id', None) p_class = self.payload_class if isinstance(data_model, data_models.HealthMonitor): model_id = data_model.pool_id p_class = PoolProducer.PAYLOAD_CLASS kw = {"{0}_updates".format(self.payload_class): updated_model.to_dict(render_unsets=False), "{0}_id".format(p_class): model_id} method_name = "update_{0}".format(self.payload_class) self.client.cast({}, method_name, **kw) def delete(self, data_model): """sends a delete message to the controller via oslo.messaging :param data_model: """ model_id = getattr(data_model, 'id', None) p_class = self.payload_class if isinstance(data_model, data_models.HealthMonitor): model_id = data_model.pool_id p_class = PoolProducer.PAYLOAD_CLASS kw = {"{0}_id".format(p_class): model_id} method_name = "delete_{0}".format(self.payload_class) self.client.cast({}, method_name, **kw) class LoadBalancerProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "load_balancer" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS def delete(self, data_model, cascade): """sends a delete message to the controller via oslo.messaging :param data_model: :param: cascade: delete listeners, etc. as well """ model_id = getattr(data_model, 'id', None) p_class = self.payload_class kw = {"{0}_id".format(p_class): model_id, "cascade": cascade} method_name = "delete_{0}".format(self.payload_class) self.client.cast({}, method_name, **kw) class ListenerProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "listener" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class PoolProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "pool" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class HealthMonitorProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "health_monitor" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class MemberProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "member" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class L7PolicyProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "l7policy" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class L7RuleProducer(BaseProducer): """Sends updates,deletes and creates to the RPC end of the queue consumer """ PAYLOAD_CLASS = "l7rule" @property def payload_class(self): return self.PAYLOAD_CLASS class ProducerHandler(abstract_handler.BaseHandler): """Base class for all QueueProducers. used to send messages via the Class variables load_balancer, listener, health_monitor, and member. """ load_balancer = LoadBalancerProducer() listener = ListenerProducer() pool = PoolProducer() health_monitor = HealthMonitorProducer() member = MemberProducer() l7policy = L7PolicyProducer() l7rule = L7RuleProducer()

commit_message:
RBD: the value of 'had_journaling' has not changed after 'update_features'.

I find that in method '_enable_replication', if the volume has no feature of
'journaling', the value of 'had_journaling' will not be changed before and
after 'update_features', it's always 'None', so, the value of 'bool(had_journaling)'
will always be 'false', this value will be written to database finally. I think that's
a bug. I change the value of 'had_journaling' after 'update_features' by
adding 'had_journaling = image.features() & self.rbd.RBD_FEATURE_JOURNALING'.

Change-Id: Iac0bd536a40fd90bd69b37044b50f68cd41586ee
Closes-Bug: #1654126
